Only one principle is there behind the orbital dynamics of boomerang and that is the theory of 'Action and Perpendicular Reaction/2012'. 'Action' is the air resistance against motion and it is bigger always upon the forward wing and smaller on the backward wing due to rotation. So the resultant air resistant is applied upon the boomerang on a plane shifted from the rotating axis. Then the boomerang starts rolling upon that resistive plane. Any rolling system centrifugal force to apart from the rolling plan. That perpendicular force is the 'reaction' and boomerang undergoes an orbital motion. As a proof you can throw it out from a space craft in to the free space and observe it 's motion along a sharp straight line. That is because no resistance is there. for more pl ref. 'The Alternative Dimension in Angular Momentum'/space dynamics

The "I've never seen" was a figure of speech. But I see know that the ISS does output the delta-V necessary to maintain orbit

Lift is needed. At around 0:35, there is an explanation and an illustration of why this is. Due to the spinning, there is a difference in air flow between the top and bottom of the boomerang such that more lift is generated on the top than on the bottom. This creates the torque that causes the boomerang's gyroscopic precession, and ultimately its return to the thrower.

I understand what you're saying, but that's not how it's explained in the video. There, he says the uneven lift across the spinning blades creates a torque, and the spin of the blades generates angular momentum. Since the torque changes the angular momentum back towards the thrower, how can the boomerang return if there is no torque caused by uneven generation of lift?
I'm not trying to be an ass; just trying to figure out how a boomerang would work in outer space. :)
It doesn't need lift in zero G. The torque created from the rotation causes an angular momentum aka gyroscopic precession.

If, as you say in the video and in the description, the boomerang uses three fundamental physics principles (lift, relative velocity, and gyroscopic precession), then how does it return to the thrower in space where no life can be created? I would agree that the other two principles would be unchanged, but with no air acting upon the airfoils, how would the uneven lift be created that results in the torque that turns the boomerang?

In the situation you described, the resultant force in the boomerang should be roughly zero. Having the boomerang change directions would mean its linear momentum is changed, contradicting Newton's first law of motion.

Ferrous material tends to be highly magnetic, yes. But magnetism has to do with the field of electrons that surround every atom. Atoms of opposing polarity will see their electron fields fit together nicely, akin to a puzzle. Atoms with the same polarity, since the "pieces" will be a mirror of one another, will push apart. These exchanges are also behind how electric currents work.
There's also very little gravitational pull in space, thus removing the need for lift. The torque is the energy expended by the person throwing it.

Actually, an electron is not affected by a magnet if the magnetic field around the electron is not changing. If the magnetic field is changing, then it affects the electron but only because a change in the magnetic field creates an electric field that exerts a force on the electron.

That's an electric field.
Magnetic fields are not electric fields. In fact, if you have a changing electric field, you have a magnetic field in the direction of the cross product of the changing electric field. They behave similarly, but the two are very different.

No. A vacuum would take away one of the principles that makes a boomerang work, lift. Without a fluid for it to move through, no lift can be achieved. Without lift, you don't get the uneven lifts of the top and bottom halves that causes the torque for it to turn.
Avatar FTW!

Torque is just force acting on an object to rotate it. Like, if you are using a ratchet, or even a better example, a torque wrench. You set the torque wrench to the specified ending torque, for example, 120 in lbs (the SI unit is N m), and continue turning the bolt until you reach the point in the turn where it takes 120 in lbs to continue rotating the bolt.

Angular momentum is pretty much this. An object in motion wants to stay in motion, right? Well an object spinning wants to keep spinning.
